Safavid invasion of Ossetia - was an invasion of the Safavid army into the mountainous part of Ossetia which occurred after the expedition to Kartli and Kakheti in 1614.
Background
In 1606, Shah Abbas made a successful campaign in Shirvan, capturing the southern part of Dagestan. However, his plans included expansion to all of Dagestan.
In 1614-1617, Shah Abbas made an expedition to Kartli and Kakheti, these expeditions were quite successful for the Safavids.
The reason for the campaign was the desire to enter the territory of Circassia and from there go to Dagestan, however, the Shah's troops, not finding a road to Dagestan, attacked the mountainous part of Ossetia.
Invasion
In 1614 the Shah arrived in the Georgian village of Nikozi and from there his troops went to Ossetia.
The Shah's troops invaded Ossetia from 2 directions. One group crossed the  and, moving through the Dargavs and  gorges, headed towards the . The second group crossed the Mamison Pass and, moving through the Mamison Pass and Alagir gorges, headed towards the Ursdon fortress. There were clashes between the Shah's troops and the local population.
The Shah's troops unsuccessfully stormed the  fortress in the Kurtat gorge. After the Shah's army invaded the Kurtat gorge, the gorge's inhabitants took refuge in the . This fortress was located at the beginning of the Kurtat Gorge, at the foot of the Rocky Range. The fortress covered a large cave, which allowed a large number of people to hide behind its walls.
After the failure to storm the fortress of Dzhivgisa, the Safavid troops went to the high-mountain village of . Despite the resistance of the locals, the village was captured, after which Shah's army moved towards the village of . While the Safavid troops were approaching the  through the forest, they were noticed by the Ossetians who set the forest on fire.
The Shah's troops attacked the fortress with cannons but this was not successful. The Safavid troops headed to the village of , and after a short resistance, when the Ossetians ran out of ammunition, they surrendered. From the village of , the troops headed to the village of Arkhon. However, the Ossetians managed to ambush the Shah's troops in the forest.
Aftermath
Due to the geographical position, which was reflected in the mountainous terrain, the Safavids were unable to capture Ossetia and from there reach Circassia.
The invasions of Shah Abbas are preserved in many Ossetian legends, and the term Shah's road was used for a long time in relation to the road that was built by the Safavids during the invasion.
In 1617, the Ossetians arrived in Kakheti to help the Georgians in their fight against the Safavids.
Despite the fact that the Ossetians, like the Georgians, suffered from constant raids by the Ottoman and Persian invaders, by the beginning of the 18th century the Ossetians managed to maintain their independence.
